awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Proximate Basis of Individual Variation in Phenotypic Plasticity
awd_abstract_narration:
In all animals, changes in access to food during growth affects final adult size; greater nutrition produces larger adults.  However, not all parts of an organism grow at the same rate, and so changes in access to nutrition during growth can affect the ultimate size of different parts of the body differently.  Although the effects of nutritional variation on relative trait size are well documented, only recently have the tools become available to (i) enable study of how genetic and developmental mechanisms manage the growth of traits to produce a properly proportioned adult and to (ii) enable study of how these mechanisms change to alter growth patterns to produce size diversity among species.  Here, the investigators will take a novel approach by changing diet in lines of fruit flies, each possessing their own unique and known genetic code, to identify the specific genes underlying the regulation and integration of growth among various parts of the body.  This research will be coupled with a new, fun elementary school computer-based learning activity where students will alter the relative growth of structures in virtual creatures, transforming young humans into fantastical beings.

Phenotypic plasticity is the ability of a genotype to express different phenotypes across environments.  It is well studied on a phenomenological level, particularly for morphological traits; phenotypic plasticity can hinder or promote adaptation, lead to the genesis of evolutionary novelties or serve as an adaptation itself.  A lack of experimental tools has meant that two components central to the evolution of morphological plasticity - the variation among individuals in the expression of plastic responses and the proximate bases of this variation - are essentially unknown.  Nutritionally-induced size variation is common to all metazoans: nutritional limitation during ontogeny generally produces smaller individuals than does a nutritionally rich diet, although the degree of nutritionally-induced size plasticity can vary dramatically among morphological traits.  Such differences in relative trait plasticity are rooted in recently identified developmental genetic mechanisms that regulate and integrate the growth of traits in response to nutritional variation.  Frankino (PI) and Shingleton (co-PI) hypothesize that variation in these same mechanisms underlies the evolutionarily important variation among genotypes in trait plasticity. Here, they propose to test this hypothesis by:  (i) applying new methods to create and quantify the among-individual variation in nutritionally-induced trait and body size plasticities; (ii) using genome-wide association mapping to identify genes that contribute to this variation, and; (iii) employing a series of developmental assays to confirm the role of these genes in producing among-individual variation in nutritionally induced size plasticity.

por.por_cntn:
The size of morphological traits (for example, limbs, wings, teeth, organs) relative to each other and to the size of the body is central to animal function and form. Environmental variation, such as variation in nutritional intake, during growth can affect body size. Consequently, growth among the constituent parts of an organism must be integrated such that proper trait proportions are achieved regardless of final adult body size; mis-regulation of growth can result in over- or under-sized traits which in turn can impede ecological function and even cause disease. Moreover, the evolution of animal form occurs primarily though changes in the size of morphological traits relative to each other or to the body. Thus, knowing how the relative growth of traits is regulated is essential to understanding the expression and evolution of animal form within and among species.

Here, we sought to determine if the genetic basis of variation among relative trait size within species is the same as that which is believed to underlie variation among relative trait size among species. We used mathematical approaches and a biological model organism, the fruit fly Drosophlia melanogaster, to explore these ideas. Our studies included i) building a developmentally-based mathematical model of relative trait size evolution, ii) determining if the pattern of nutritionally-induced changes in size of morphological traits is the same or dissimilar among traits within individuals, iii) among individuals for the same traits, and iv) the degree to which these patterns hold between sexes. Finally, we sought to identify the genetic loci responsible for these patterns of variation in trait size and to compare them across groups.

Our mathematical model reveals that the pattern of variation in relative trait size among individuals in a population critically determines how the population will respond to natural selection; the same pattern of selection can generate opposite responses to selection, depending on the distribution of relative trait size in the population. With this information in hand, we determined that the pattern of relative trait sizes changed differently with body size among genetically distinct lineages of D. melanogaster, creating the kinds of variation in the slope of trait-body size scaling relationships our mathematical model identified as being evolutionarily important. Interestingly, body size variation proved to be key in understanding these patterns. Variation in trait-body size scaling relationship slopes was caused primarily by disproportional changes in the size of the body relative to the size of other morphological traits – the opposite of our expectations that variation in trait size would be most important. In addition, the relative size relationships held consistently between sexes from the same lineage, even though females are larger than males. Finally, while this sex-specific size dimorphism is consistent, we found that females responded to increases in nutrition more, and more variably, than males, increasing body and trait size more than males when nutrition is abundant.

The high variation in relative trait size across body sizes among genetic lineages of flies we document indicates that many genetic loci affect relative trait size, that there are many genetic variants at these loci, or both. They might also indicate complex non-additive interactions among variants at these loci. Conversely, the consistent trait:body size relationships between sexes from the same lineage indicate that, the variants at relative size-regulating loci act similarly within genetically unique individuals, at least with respect to the morphological traits we studied.

Using published genetic data, we attempted to associate the identities of genetic variants across all loci and the patterns of relative trait:body size relationships we observed among the lineages we studied. Much to our surprise, the genetic loci (e.g., several within the insulin signaling pathway) shown experimentally to be capable of affecting relative trait size within species, and these same loci known to affect relative trait size among species, were not associated with variation among genetic lineages within our study population. Possible causes for this lack of association are many, including, a limited number (ca. 200) lineages under study, complex genetics (e.g., strong non-additive interactions among variants across genetic loci), and a difference between the genetic basis of variation within populations as compared to those among species. We are working to assemble this complicated genetic puzzle. Because non-additive interactions among variants across loci prevents those variants from contributing easily to the response to natural selection, the subset of variants that contribute to relative trait size in a straightforward, additive manner may be more likely to be seized by selection to produce morphological differences among species. Resolution of the genetics of within- versus among-species variation in relative trait size will thus not only deepen our understanding of the expression and evolution of animal form, but it will also address long standing questions regarding the genetics of diversification itself.
